block.p: Criticism Exposes Rift In Kremlin Over Oil Stocks Russia's prime minister criticized the freezing of a large block of shares in the Yukos Oil Company. His statement verged on open defiance of a warning from President Vladimir V. Putin against ministerial meddling in the case and exposed deepening rifts in the Kremlin.

Anton V. Drel became the official counsel of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest tycoon, and soon after, a prosecutor presented Mr. Drel with a summons to be questioned as a witness. The move was the latest in a series of aggressive and, lawyers say, illegal tactics in the investigation.

Call to Anti-U.S. Muslims Across Europe and the Middle East, young militant Muslim men are answering a rallying cry issued by Osama bin Laden and others to join the fight against the American-led occupation in Iraq.
Another American soldier died during a battle between guerrillas and American troops after a demonstration in support of Saddam Hussein turned violent.

G.I. Dies in Afghanistan An American Special Forces soldier has died from wounds sustained during an operation against suspected Taliban fighters in southern Afghanistan. He is the third American to die in fighting in Afghanistan in less than a week.

Holy Site Blocked by Israel Israel blocked some Palestinian Muslims from reaching a holy site to pray in Jerusalem, while in Tel Aviv vandals defaced a memorial to Yitzhak Rabin, a day before a ceremony to commemorate the prime minister's assassination in 1995.

Malaysian Leader Leaves Asia's longest-serving leader, Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, stepped down and handed power to a handpicked successor, Abdullah Badawi, 63, in a ceremony in the new government capital, Putrajaya.

A Few Houses Stand Among Many Fire Ruins Thousands of houses in neighborhoods across Southern California have been destroyed in the past week by wildfires. A few houses have been spared, however, leaving their owners with a roof over their heads but without a single neighbor.
Aided by wet weather and light winds, firefighters appeared to get the upper hand on southern California's wildfires.
Researchers Build Lethal Virus Scientists have created a highly lethal virus in an effort to develop stronger protections against the threat of supervirulent forms of smallpox, researchers said.

3 Suits Against Abortion Ban Opponents of an expected federal law prohibiting a specific abortion procedure filed three suits seeking to overturn the ban on the grounds that it would be overly broad and unconstitutional. President Bush is widely expected to sign the bill soon.
Party Leaders Seek '04 Signs Party leaders are looking to the South, where three states will hold elections for governor, for signs of favorable trends for November 2004.
Gephardt's Evolution Richard A. Gephardt's decision to turn the spotlight on his daughter, Crissy, who is openly gay, underscores his own evolution during 27 years in Congress.

President-Elect Vacates Post Daniel S. Goldin, the former NASA administrator, agreed to walk away from the presidency of Boston University for a reported payment of $1.8 million just one day before he was to take over as the trustees' unanimous choice.

Ferry Safety Reports Show Accidents and Errors A review of 1,500 Coast Guard safety reports over the last 25 years shows that Staten Island ferries have been involved in dozens of accidents that injured hundreds, and were often attributed to human error -- chiefly what investigators called inattentiveness, poor judgment or negligence by crew members.

Judicial Appointment Battles Senator Charles Schumer has used every tactic available to block the appointment of judges nominated by the Bush administration, drawing fire from the political right for both his methodology and his success.

Problems at Collapse Site Union leaders questioned if pressure they said their members felt to speed up the Tropicana Casino and Resort construction job might have been a factor in the collapse of a parking garage that killed four people.

Seeking Back Pay for Tubman The Senate has included $11,750 in an appropriations bill, a pension for military service by Harriet Tubman's second husband. Despite the gesture, the Civil War heroine, above left, has yet to receive a pension for her service as a scout or a spy.
Bible's Race Implications The tale in Genesis 9 of how Noah cursed the descendants of his son Ham is a way for scholars to explore how and why people began to see themselves as racially divided.
More Clients Leave Putnam Several pension funds and university endowments fired Putnam Investments as their money manager, since it was accused of securities fraud on Tuesday.
Business Spending Picks Up Business spending on information technology played a role in the robust economic growth last quarter.
Outlook on Russia Confirmed Foreign oil companies say the fight over Russia's biggest oil concern, Yukos, confirms that Russia, for all its changes, is not like the West.
Strong Week for Stocks The Dow rose 14.51 points to 9,801.12, 218.66 points higher than last week's close. The Nasdaq fell 0.48 point, to 1,932,21, 66.62 points above last week's close.
Editorials: A plan to import drugs safely; promising start on global warming; unconstitutional farm checkoffs; an actual judicial election.
